Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, as the clock ticked past six. My wife’s text flashed on my phone: “Can you talk? I really need you.” She’d been struggling for weeks, and I promised I’d be there whenever she needed to talk. But just as I reached for my phone, my screen lit up with a call—my supervisor’s number. I had to take it. On the other end, a customer’s voice crackled, sharp and angry, demanding to know why our offer was worth their time. My manager expected me to handle objections smoothly, to keep the customer on the line, to not let the company down. But my wife’s messages kept coming, each one more desperate. My heart pounded as I tried to listen to the customer’s accusations, my mind split between the script I was supposed to follow and the words I wanted to say to comfort my wife. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding all of me, and I didn’t know which voice to answer first.
